description: Comprehensive common mistakes from AP Precalculus exam data - 50+ critical errors organized by unit and topic
purpose: Proactive error prevention, targeted intervention, and self-verification for AI tutor responses

mistakes.correct: (f \circ g)(x) = f(g(x)) \neq (g \circ f)(x) = g(f(x))
mistakes.why: Function composition is not commutative. Order matters critically - must apply inner function first.
mistakes.remedy: Always work from inside out. Read f(g(x)) as 'f of g of x' - apply g first, then f to the result. Mnemonic: read composition right to left.
mistakes.example: If f(x) = x^2 and g(x) = x+1: (f \circ g)(2) = f(g(2)) = f(3) = 9, but (g \circ f)(2) = g(f(2)) = g(4) = 5

mistakes.correct: f^{-1}(x) \text{ is the inverse function that undoes f, NOT the reciprocal } \frac{1}{f(x)}
mistakes.why: The notation f^{-1} means inverse function (reverses the operation), not reciprocal. These are completely different concepts.
mistakes.remedy: Remember: inverse function undoes the operation. If f doubles, f^{-1} halves. The reciprocal 1/f(x) should be written as [f(x)]^{-1}. To find inverse: swap x and y, then solve for y.
mistakes.example: If f(x) = 2x + 1, then f^{-1}(x) = \frac{x-1}{2} (undoes the operation), NOT \frac{1}{2x+1}. Verify: f(f^{-1}(5)) = f(2) = 5 \checkmark

mistakes.correct: \text{Generally } f(x+y) \neq f(x) + f(y) \text{ (only true for linear } f(x) = mx \text{ with no constant)}
mistakes.why: Functions don't distribute over addition unless they are linear with zero y-intercept. Must substitute the entire input.
mistakes.remedy: Substitute the entire input as one unit. f(2x) means replace every x with 2x in the formula. Only linear functions f(x)=mx distribute this way.

mistakes.mistake: f(x-2) \text{ shifts the graph LEFT 2 units}
mistakes.correct: f(x-2) \text{ shifts the graph RIGHT 2 units (opposite of intuition)}
mistakes.why: Inside transformations work opposite: subtracting shifts right, adding shifts left. Think: to get the same output earlier, x must be larger.
mistakes.remedy: Method 1: Set the inside equal to zero: x-2=0 gives x=2, so the origin moves to x=2 (right). Method 2: Think 'opposite day' for horizontal shifts.
mistakes.example: f(x-2) = (x-2)^2 has vertex at x=2 (2 units right), not x=-2. For f(x+3), vertex is at x=-3 (3 units left).

mistakes.correct: 2f(x) \text{ is vertical stretch by 2, } f(2x) \text{ is horizontal compression by factor of 2}
mistakes.why: Multiplying output stretches vertically (makes taller); multiplying input compresses horizontally (makes narrower). Factors work opposite directions horizontally.
mistakes.remedy: Outside the function affects y (vertical), inside affects x (horizontal). For horizontal: larger coefficient means narrower graph (opposite of vertical).
mistakes.example: f(2x) makes graph half as wide (compressed), not stretched. If f(x) = x^2, then f(2x) = 4x^2 is narrower.

mistakes.mistake: \text{Domain of } (f \circ g)(x) \text{ is just the domain of } f
mistakes.correct: \text{Domain is all } x \text{ where } g(x) \text{ is defined AND } g(x) \in \text{domain of } f
mistakes.why: Must check both conditions: (1) g must accept x as input, and (2) f must accept g(x) as input.
mistakes.remedy: Two-step check: (1) What x values can g handle? (2) For those x, does g(x) land in f's domain?
mistakes.example: If f(x) = \sqrt{x} (domain [0,\infty)) and g(x) = x-5, then domain of f(g(x)) is [5, \infty), not [0, \infty). Need x-5 \geq 0.

mistakes.mistake: \text{Even function means } f(2), f(4), f(6) \text{ are defined}
mistakes.correct: \text{Even function means } f(-x) = f(x) \text{ for all x (y-axis symmetry)}
mistakes.why: Even/odd refers to symmetry properties, not which inputs work. It's about the algebraic relationship f(-x) vs f(x).
mistakes.remedy: Test with negative inputs: if f(-x) = f(x) for all x → even (mirror across y-axis). If f(-x) = -f(x) → odd (rotate 180° around origin).
mistakes.example: f(x) = x^2 is even because f(-3) = 9 = f(3). f(x) = x^3 is odd because f(-2) = -8 = -f(2).

mistakes.mistake: \text{Zero of multiplicity 2 means graph crosses x-axis twice}
mistakes.correct: \text{Even multiplicity: graph touches but doesn't cross. Odd multiplicity: graph crosses}
mistakes.why: Multiplicity describes behavior at one zero. Even = bounce off, odd = pass through.
mistakes.remedy: Think of it like bouncing: even multiplicity bounces off x-axis without crossing. Odd multiplicity passes straight through.
mistakes.example: f(x) = (x-2)^2(x+1) has multiplicity 2 at x=2 (touches), multiplicity 1 at x=-1 (crosses).

mistakes.mistake: \text{Cancelled factors in rational functions create vertical asymptotes}
mistakes.correct: \text{Cancelled factors create holes. Non-cancelled zeros in denominator create asymptotes}
mistakes.why: Cancellation removes the discontinuity from simplified form, leaving only a hole (removable discontinuity).
mistakes.remedy: Factor completely, then: (1) Cancel common factors → holes at those x-values. (2) Remaining zeros in denominator → vertical asymptotes.
mistakes.example: f(x) = \frac{(x-2)(x+1)}{(x-2)(x-3)} = \frac{x+1}{x-3} has hole at x=2, vertical asymptote at x=3.

mistakes.mistake: \text{All rational functions have horizontal asymptote } y=0
mistakes.correct: \text{Compare degrees: top < bottom } \to y=0; \text{ top = bottom } \to y = \frac{\text{leading coefficients}}{\text{...}}; \text{ top > bottom } \to \text{ no HA}
mistakes.why: End behavior depends on growth rates of numerator vs denominator as x→±∞.
mistakes.remedy: Degree comparison: (1) numerator smaller → HA at y=0. (2) equal → HA at ratio of leading coefficients. (3) numerator larger → no HA (may have slant asymptote).
mistakes.example: f(x) = \frac{2x^2+1}{x^2-3} has HA y=2 (ratio 2/1). g(x) = \frac{x^3}{x^2+1} has no HA (top degree larger).

mistakes.correct: |x-2| < 3 \text{ means } -3 < x-2 < 3, \text{ so } -1 < x < 5
mistakes.why: Absolute value inequality |A| < B means -B < A < B (distance from zero less than B).
mistakes.remedy: For |expr| < k: write -k < expr < k. For |expr| > k: write expr > k OR expr < -k (two separate regions).
mistakes.example: |x+1| \leq 4 means -4 \leq x+1 \leq 4, so -5 \leq x \leq 3.

mistakes.correct: \sin^{-1}(x) = \arcsin(x) \text{ (returns an angle)}, \text{ while } \csc(x) = \frac{1}{\sin(x)}
mistakes.why: The -1 exponent for trig functions means inverse function (arcsin), NOT reciprocal. This is the #1 trig notation error.
mistakes.remedy: Use arcsin notation to avoid confusion. Remember: sin^{-1}(0.5) asks 'what angle has sine = 0.5?' Answer: 30° or π/6. Compare: csc(30°) = 1/sin(30°) = 2.
mistakes.example: \sin^{-1}(1/2) = \pi/6 \text{ (an angle)}, while \csc(\pi/6) = \frac{1}{\sin(\pi/6)} = 2 \text{ (a ratio)}. Totally different!

mistakes.mistake: \sin(30) = 0.5 \text{ when calculator is in radian mode}
mistakes.correct: \sin(30°) = 0.5, \text{ but } \sin(30 \text{ radians}) \approx -0.988
mistakes.why: 30 radians ≈ 1718°, a completely different angle. Must convert units or set calculator to correct mode.
mistakes.remedy: Always specify units explicitly. Use π for radians (sin(π/6) not sin(30)). Check calculator mode before computing. AP Precalc primarily uses radians.
mistakes.example: \sin(\pi/6) = 0.5 \text{ (radian mode)}. \sin(30°) = 0.5 \text{ (degree mode)}. \sin(30) \approx -0.988 \text{ (30 radians!)}

mistakes.correct: \text{Period} = \frac{2\pi}{|B|} \text{ where B is coefficient of x, so period } = \frac{2\pi}{2} = \pi
mistakes.why: Period depends ONLY on the coefficient of x (frequency), NOT on phase shift or vertical shift.
mistakes.remedy: For y = A·sin(Bx + C) + D, period = 2π/|B|. Ignore A, C, and D when finding period. Only B matters.
mistakes.example: y = 5\sin(3x - 7) + 2 has period 2\pi/3. The 5, -7, and +2 don't affect period at all.

mistakes.correct: \text{Must factor: } y = \sin(2(x-\pi/2)), \text{ so phase shift is } \pi/2 \text{ to the RIGHT}
mistakes.why: Must factor out coefficient of x to find true phase shift. Formula: y = A·sin(B(x - C/B)).
mistakes.remedy: Factor out B: y = A·sin(B(x - h)) + D where h = -C/B is phase shift. Positive h = right, negative h = left.
mistakes.example: y = \cos(3x + 6) = \cos(3(x + 2)), phase shift is 2 LEFT (not 6 left). y = \sin(2x - \pi) = \sin(2(x - \pi/2)), phase shift is \pi/2 RIGHT.

mistakes.correct: \text{Amplitude is } |A| = 3 \text{ (always positive). Negative A reflects across x-axis}
mistakes.why: Amplitude measures distance from midline, which is always positive. The sign of A determines reflection, not amplitude.
mistakes.remedy: Amplitude = |A| in y = A·sin(Bx + C) + D. Always take absolute value. Negative A flips the graph vertically.
mistakes.example: y = -5\cos(x) + 2 has amplitude 5, midline y=2, and is reflected (starts at minimum instead of maximum).

mistakes.mistake: \text{All trig values are positive in Quadrant II}
mistakes.correct: \text{Q1: all positive, Q2: sin positive only, Q3: tan positive only, Q4: cos positive only}
mistakes.why: Mnemonic: 'All Students Take Calculus' - Q1: All, Q2: Sin, Q3: Tan, Q4: Cos are positive.
mistakes.remedy: Remember ASTC starting from Q1 going counterclockwise. Or think: Q2 is upper-left (y>0, x<0), so sin=y is +, cos=x is -, tan=y/x is -.

mistakes.correct: \text{Reference angle is } \pi - 5\pi/6 = \pi/6 \text{ (acute angle to nearest x-axis)}
mistakes.why: Reference angle is always the acute angle (0 to π/2) to the x-axis. Used to find trig values by checking quadrant for signs.
mistakes.remedy: Formulas: Q1: θ itself, Q2: π-θ, Q3: θ-π, Q4: 2π-θ. Result must be in [0, π/2].
mistakes.example: For 7\pi/4 (Q4): reference = 2\pi - 7\pi/4 = \pi/4. For 2\pi/3 (Q2): reference = \pi - 2\pi/3 = \pi/3.

mistakes.correct: \sin^{-1}(1/2) = \pi/6 \text{ only. Range of arcsin is } [-\pi/2, \pi/2]
mistakes.why: Inverse trig functions must return single values to be functions. Ranges are restricted: arcsin ∈ [-π/2, π/2], arccos ∈ [0, π], arctan ∈ (-π/2, π/2).
mistakes.remedy: Memorize restricted ranges. arcsin and arctan return angles in [-π/2, π/2] (right side of circle). arccos returns angles in [0, π] (top half).
mistakes.example: \sin(5\pi/6) = 1/2 \text{ (true)}, but \sin^{-1}(1/2) = \pi/6 \text{ only (Q1)}. To get 5π/6, solve sin(x)=1/2 separately.

mistakes.mistake: \text{Tangent has period } 2\pi \text{ like sine and cosine}
mistakes.correct: \tan(x) \text{ has period } \pi, \text{ not } 2\pi \text{ (repeats twice as fast)}
mistakes.why: tan(x) = sin(x)/cos(x). Both numerator and denominator change signs together after π, so tan repeats every π.
mistakes.remedy: Period of tan(Bx) is π/|B|. For sin/cos it's 2π/|B|. Tangent completes full cycle in half the distance.
mistakes.example: \tan(0) = 0, \tan(\pi) = 0, \tan(2\pi) = 0. Graph repeats every π, not 2π.

mistakes.mistake: \text{Coterminal angles and reference angles are the same thing}
mistakes.correct: \text{Coterminal: same terminal side (differ by } 2\pi). \text{ Reference: acute angle to x-axis}
mistakes.why: Different concepts. Coterminal angles have same trig values. Reference angles help find trig values using acute angle and quadrant signs.
mistakes.remedy: Coterminal: add/subtract 2π (360°). Reference: find acute angle to x-axis (always positive, ≤ π/2).
mistakes.example: 5\pi/6 and 17\pi/6 are coterminal (differ by 2π). Both have reference angle π/6.

mistakes.correct: \text{General solution: } x = \pi/6 + 2\pi n \text{ and } x = 5\pi/6 + 2\pi n \text{ for integer } n
mistakes.why: Trig functions are periodic. Unless domain is restricted, must give all solutions using periodicity.
mistakes.remedy: Find solutions in [0, 2π), then add 2πn for sine/cosine, or πn for tangent. Check if domain restricts answers.
mistakes.example: \cos(x) = 0 gives x = \pi/2 + \pi n (includes π/2, 3π/2, 5π/2, -π/2, ...). If domain is [0, 2π), just x = π/2, 3π/2.

mistakes.correct: \log(ab) = \log(a) + \log(b) \text{ (product rule, NOT sum rule!)}
mistakes.why: There is NO logarithm property for addition or subtraction inside the log. Only products, quotients, and powers have properties.
mistakes.remedy: Remember: logs turn multiplication→addition, division→subtraction, powers→multiplication. They NEVER split sums or differences.
mistakes.example: \log(2+3) = \log(5) \neq \log(2) + \log(3) = \log(6). Test: log(5)≈0.699, log(6)≈0.778 - different!

mistakes.correct: \log(a/b) = \log(a) - \log(b) \text{ (quotient rule, NOT difference!)}
mistakes.why: Subtraction of logs means division inside, not subtraction inside. Logs don't distribute over subtraction.
mistakes.remedy: Log properties: ×→+, ÷→-, power→×. Addition/subtraction inside log stays as-is.

mistakes.correct: \ln(x) \text{ is base } e \approx 2.718, \log(x) \text{ is usually base } 10
mistakes.why: Different bases give different values. ln is natural log (base e), log is common log (base 10) in most precalc contexts.
mistakes.remedy: ln = loge (natural), log = log₁₀ (common) unless context specifies otherwise. In calculus, 'log' often means ln.
mistakes.example: \ln(10) \approx 2.303, \text{ but } \log(10) = 1. \ln(e) = 1, \log(e) \approx 0.434.

mistakes.correct: \ln(-5) \text{ is undefined. Domain of log is } (0, \infty) \text{ - positive numbers only}
mistakes.why: Cannot raise positive base to any real power and get negative result. Logs of negatives are undefined (in real numbers).
mistakes.remedy: Always check domain: argument of log must be positive. For ln(x-5), need x-5>0, so x>5.
mistakes.example: To solve \ln(x-3) = 2: get x-3 = e^2, so x = e^2+3 ≈ 10.39. Check: x=10.39>3 ✓. If we got x=1, reject (not in domain).

mistakes.mistake: \text{To solve } 2^x = 8, \text{ divide both sides by 2 to get } x = 4
mistakes.correct: \text{Take log of both sides: } \log(2^x) = \log(8) \Rightarrow x\log(2) = \log(8) \Rightarrow x = 3
mistakes.why: Can't divide by base when variable is in exponent. Must use logarithms to 'bring down' the exponent using power rule.
mistakes.remedy: For exponential equations: (1) Isolate exponential term. (2) Take log of both sides. (3) Use power rule to bring variable down. (4) Solve.
mistakes.example: 3^x = 27: Take ln of both sides → x\ln(3) = \ln(27) → x = \ln(27)/\ln(3) = 3. Alternatively, recognize 27=3^3.

mistakes.correct: \text{Continuous: } A = Pe^{rt}. \text{ Periodic: } A = P(1 + r/n)^{nt}
mistakes.why: Continuous compounding uses natural exponential e. Periodic compounding uses (1+r/n)^nt where n is compounds per year.
mistakes.remedy: Memorize: Continuous uses e (A=Pe^rt). Annual: (1+r)^t. n times/year: (1+r/n)^nt. As n→∞, periodic approaches continuous.
mistakes.example: $1000 at 5% for 2 years. Continuous: A = 1000e^{0.05·2} ≈ $1105.17. Annual: A = 1000(1.05)^2 = $1102.50. Continuous is higher.

mistakes.mistake: \text{After two half-lives, nothing remains (it's all gone)}
mistakes.correct: \text{After two half-lives, } (1/2)^2 = 1/4 = 25\% \text{ remains}
mistakes.why: Each half-life cuts amount in half. It approaches zero exponentially but never reaches zero in finite time.
mistakes.remedy: After n half-lives: fraction remaining = (1/2)^n. After 1: 50%, after 2: 25%, after 3: 12.5%, etc. Never fully decays.
mistakes.example: Radioactive sample with 10 year half-life. Start: 100g. After 10yr: 50g. After 20yr: 25g. After 30yr: 12.5g. Formula: A(t) = 100(1/2)^{t/10}.

mistakes.correct: \log(x^2) = 2\log(x) \text{ (exponent comes out front as coefficient)}
mistakes.why: Power rule brings exponent out as multiplier, doesn't apply it to the log itself.
mistakes.remedy: Power rule: log(a^n) = n·log(a). Exponent multiplies log, doesn't exponentiate it. This is how we solve exponential equations.

mistakes.correct: \log_2(8) = \frac{\log(8)}{\log(2)} \text{ or } \frac{\ln(8)}{\ln(2)} \text{ (change of base)}
mistakes.why: To convert logarithm to different base: divide by log of the base. Formula: log_b(x) = log_c(x)/log_c(b).
mistakes.remedy: Change of base: log_b(x) = ln(x)/ln(b) or log(x)/log(b). Denominator is log of the BASE.

mistakes.mistake: e \approx 10 \text{ or thinking } e^x \text{ and } 10^x \text{ are interchangeable}
mistakes.correct: e \approx 2.71828... \text{ is a specific mathematical constant, different from 10}
mistakes.why: e is the natural base for continuous growth, unique because derivative of e^x equals e^x. It's not 10.
mistakes.remedy: e is like π - a specific important constant. e ≈ 2.718, appears in calculus, continuous growth, probability, etc.
mistakes.example: e^2 \approx 7.389, \text{ but } 10^2 = 100. e^1 \approx 2.718, but 10^1 = 10. Very different!

mistakes.correct: \log(0) \text{ is undefined, but } \ln(1) = 0 \text{ (and } \log(1) = 0)
mistakes.why: log_b(1) = 0 for any base because b^0=1. log_b(0) is undefined because no power gives 0.
mistakes.remedy: Remember: log_b(b)=1 (b^1=b) and log_b(1)=0 (b^0=1). log_b(0) doesn't exist.

unit4-calculus-intro.name: Unit 4: Rational Functions and Introduction to Calculus

mistakes.correct: \text{Limit at a may exist even when f(a) is undefined or has different value}
mistakes.why: Limits describe approaching behavior, not value at the point. Function can have hole, jump, or be undefined at a.
mistakes.remedy: Limit asks 'where is f headed as x→a?' not 'what is f(a)?' Check three separately: left limit, right limit, function value.
mistakes.example: \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin(x)}{x} = 1, \text{ but } f(0) \text{ is undefined (0/0)}. Limit exists without function value existing.

mistakes.mistake: \text{Continuous means smooth (no sharp corners or cusps)}
mistakes.correct: \text{Continuous means no breaks/jumps/holes. Can have corners (e.g., } |x|)
mistakes.why: Continuity: can draw without lifting pencil. Smoothness (differentiability) is stronger - requires no corners. Smooth ⊂ Continuous.
mistakes.remedy: Three types: (1) Continuous and smooth (x²). (2) Continuous but not smooth (|x| at 0). (3) Not continuous (1/x at 0).
mistakes.example: f(x) = |x| is continuous everywhere (no breaks) but not differentiable at x=0 (sharp corner). g(x) = x^2 is both continuous and smooth everywhere.

mistakes.mistake: \text{Average rate of change equals instantaneous rate of change}
mistakes.correct: \text{Average: } \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a} \text{ (secant). Instantaneous: } f'(x) \text{ (tangent)}
mistakes.why: Average is over interval (slope of secant line). Instantaneous is at a point (slope of tangent, limit as interval→0).
mistakes.remedy: Average: slope between two points. Instantaneous: limit of average as interval shrinks to zero (derivative).
mistakes.example: For f(x)=x^2 from x=1 to x=3: average = (9-1)/(3-1) = 4. But instantaneous at x=2 is f'(2)=4. They happen to equal here!

mistakes.correct: \frac{dy}{dx} \text{ is ONE symbol (Leibniz notation) for derivative, not a fraction}
mistakes.why: It's differential notation representing instantaneous rate. In basic differentiation, treat as atomic symbol, not manipulable fraction.
mistakes.remedy: At precalc level, dy/dx is one symbol meaning 'derivative of y with respect to x.' In calc, it CAN sometimes be manipulated, but not arbitrarily.
mistakes.example: If y = x^2, then dy/dx = 2x. This doesn't mean dy = 2x/dx or dx/dy = 1/(2x) at precalc level.

mistakes.mistake: \text{Function can NEVER cross its horizontal asymptote}
mistakes.correct: \text{Functions CAN cross horizontal asymptotes (but not vertical ones)}
mistakes.why: Horizontal asymptote describes end behavior as x→±∞. Function can cross in the middle. Vertical asymptote means undefined, so can't cross.
mistakes.remedy: Horizontal asymptote: end behavior only, can cross anywhere. Vertical asymptote: function undefined there, cannot exist at that x.
mistakes.example: f(x) = \frac{x\sin(x)}{x^2+1} has HA y=0 but crosses it infinitely often. But VA at x=a means f(a) undefined forever.

mistakes.mistake: \lim_{x \to 2^+} f(x) \text{ means the limit value is positive}
mistakes.correct: x \to 2^+ \text{ means approaching from RIGHT (x>2), not that result is positive}
mistakes.why: Superscript ± indicates direction of approach (from which side), NOT the sign of the limit value.
mistakes.remedy: + means from right (larger x). - means from left (smaller x). The result can be any value, including negative or zero.
mistakes.example: \lim_{x \to 0^-} \frac{1}{x} = -\infty (approaching from left gives negative infinity, not positive).

mistakes.mistake: \text{All discontinuities in rational functions are vertical asymptotes}
mistakes.correct: \text{Holes are removable (cancelled factors). Asymptotes are non-removable (denominator zero)}
mistakes.why: If factor cancels: limit exists, finite, but function undefined → hole. If denominator zero after simplification → vertical asymptote.
mistakes.remedy: Factor and simplify. Cancelled factors → holes (removable discontinuity). Remaining denominator zeros → VAs (non-removable).
mistakes.example: f(x) = \frac{x^2-4}{x-2} = \frac{(x-2)(x+2)}{x-2} = x+2 \text{ for } x \neq 2. Hole at x=2, not asymptote. lim_{x\to 2}f(x)=4 exists.

mistakes.correct: \text{Increasing means as x increases, f(x) increases (positive slope, not positive value)}
mistakes.why: Increasing describes trend (slope), not sign of output. Function can be negative and still increasing.
mistakes.remedy: Increasing: moving right, graph goes up (f'(x)>0). Positive: f(x)>0 (above x-axis). Independent properties.
mistakes.example: f(x) = x - 10 is increasing everywhere (slope=1>0) but negative for x<10. At x=5: f(5)=-5 (negative value) but still increasing.

mistakes.correct: \text{Concave up means rate of change is increasing (second derivative positive)}
mistakes.why: Concavity describes how slope changes, not slope itself. Can be decreasing and concave up (slope negative but getting less negative).
mistakes.remedy: Concave up: holds water, slope increasing (f''>0). Can have f' positive (increasing), negative (decreasing), or zero (flat momentarily).
mistakes.example: f(x) = x^2 - 10x on [0,5]: concave up everywhere (f''=2>0) but decreasing (f'=2x-10<0 for x<5). Slope goes from -10 to 0.

mistakes.correct: \infty - \infty \text{ and } \frac{\infty}{\infty} \text{ are indeterminate. } \frac{c}{\infty} = 0 \text{ for finite c}
mistakes.why: Infinity is not a number. ∞-∞ and ∞/∞ are indeterminate forms needing further analysis. But c/∞=0 for constants.
mistakes.remedy: Cannot do arithmetic with ∞. Indeterminate forms (0/0, ∞/∞, ∞-∞, etc.) need limits, algebra, or L'Hôpital's rule. c/∞→0, c·∞→∞.
mistakes.example: \lim_{x\to\infty}(x^2-x) is ∞-∞ form but = ∞ (factor: x(x-1)→∞). \lim_{x\to\infty}\frac{x}{x^2} is ∞/∞ form but = 0.

mistakes.correct: \frac{a}{b} + \frac{c}{d} = \frac{ad + bc}{bd} \text{ (common denominator required)}
mistakes.why: Cannot add fractions by adding numerators and denominators. Must find common denominator first.
mistakes.remedy: Find LCD (least common denominator), convert both fractions, then add numerators only. Denominators stay the same.

mistakes.correct: \sqrt{a+b} \neq \sqrt{a} + \sqrt{b} \text{ (root doesn't distribute over addition)}
mistakes.why: Square root only distributes over multiplication (√(ab)=√a·√b), NEVER over addition. If it did, Pythagorean theorem would be trivial.
mistakes.remedy: Only distribute roots over products and quotients: √(ab)=√a·√b, √(a/b)=√a/√b. Sums and differences stay inside.
mistakes.example: \sqrt{9+16} = \sqrt{25} = 5, \text{ but } \sqrt{9}+\sqrt{16} = 3+4 = 7 \neq 5. Pythagorean: c=√(a²+b²) can't simplify.

mistakes.correct: (a+b)^2 = a^2 + 2ab + b^2 \text{ (FOIL or binomial formula)}
mistakes.why: Squaring a sum isn't same as summing squares. The cross term 2ab is critical and often forgotten.
mistakes.remedy: Remember: (a+b)²=(a+b)(a+b), FOIL gives a²+ab+ba+b²=a²+2ab+b². Or memorize formula. Never drop middle term.
mistakes.example: (x+3)^2 \neq x^2+9. Correct: x^2+6x+9. Test with x=1: (1+3)²=16, but 1²+9=10 ≠ 16.

mistakes.correct: x^{-2} = \frac{1}{x^2} \text{ (negative exponent means reciprocal, not negative)}
mistakes.why: Negative exponent flips to denominator, doesn't make value negative. a^{-n}=1/a^n.
mistakes.remedy: a^{-n} = 1/a^n. Move between numerator/denominator and flip sign of exponent. Doesn't make result negative.

mistakes.correct: \text{Cannot cancel terms in addition. Can only cancel common FACTORS}
mistakes.why: Cancellation works for factors (multiplication), not terms (addition). Must factor first.
mistakes.remedy: Only cancel factors: \frac{x(x+3)}{x(x+5)} = \frac{x+3}{x+5}. Never cancel terms: \frac{x+3}{x+5} cannot simplify.

mistakes.correct: 2 + 3 \times 4 = 2 + 12 = 14 \text{ (multiply before adding - PEMDAS)}
mistakes.why: Order of operations: Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication/Division (left to right), Addition/Subtraction (left to right).
mistakes.remedy: PEMDAS (or BODMAS). Do multiplication/division before addition/subtraction unless parentheses say otherwise.
mistakes.example: 10 - 2 \times 3 = 10 - 6 = 4, \text{ NOT } (10-2) \times 3 = 24. Also: 10/2×3 = 5×3 = 15 (left to right).

mistakes.correct: x^0 = 1 \text{ for any } x \neq 0
mistakes.why: By exponent rules: x^0 = x^{n-n} = x^n/x^n = 1. It's a definition that makes exponent laws consistent.
mistakes.remedy: Any non-zero number to the zero power is 1. Only exception: 0^0 is indeterminate.

mistakes.correct: (ab)^n = a^n b^n \text{ IS correct (exponent distributes over products)}
mistakes.why: This one actually works! Exponents distribute over multiplication, just not over addition.
mistakes.remedy: Correct distributions: (ab)^n = a^n·b^n, (a/b)^n = a^n/b^n. Incorrect: (a+b)^n ≠ a^n + b^n.

verificationRules.description: Self-check rules for AI to avoid making these mistakes in responses
rules: Before stating any algebraic simplification, verify with a numerical example
When using logarithm properties, explicitly state which property and verify it only applies to products/quotients/powers
Always specify angle units (degrees or radians) when giving trigonometric values
Check domain restrictions before and after any algebraic manipulation - note if factors were cancelled
Verify each equation step maintains mathematical equivalence - use ⇒ for implications, ⇔ for equivalences
Never distribute operations that don't distribute: roots over sums, logs over sums, exponents over sums
For function notation: clearly distinguish f^{-1}(x) (inverse) from [f(x)]^{-1} (reciprocal)
When stating trig identities or solving trig equations, verify using unit circle or known values
For limits, separately check: (1) left limit, (2) right limit, (3) function value, (4) do they match?
Cross-reference solutions with notation table and golden words for correct terminology
When in doubt, leave expressions in exact form rather than simplifying incorrectly
For rational functions, factor completely first, then identify holes vs asymptotes

pedagogicalNotes.description: Teaching strategies for common mistake patterns
strategies: For notation confusions (f^{-1} vs 1/f): Use verbal descriptions alongside symbols
For distribution errors: Show counterexamples with numbers before algebraic work
For trig mistakes: Always connect to unit circle and right triangle meanings
For log errors: Emphasize logs turn operations into simpler operations (× → +, etc.)
For limit mistakes: Use graphical intuition and tables of values
For transformation errors: Use test points to verify direction of shifts
Encourage exact answers (√2, π, e) over decimals to avoid precision issues
Use dimensional analysis and unit checking as error-detection tool
